p: Dengue virus (DENV) is a growing threat to public health, with nearly 390 million infections every year worldwide, of which ~96 million are symptomatic [ 1, 2]. An estimated 2.5 billion people are at risk of dengue infection [ 3]. Dengue is regarded as the world’s most important mosquito-borne viral disease and is endemic in more than 100 countries [ 4], with most disease burden limited to tropical and subtropical regions [ 5]. However, in 2014 an outbreak of dengue occurred in Japan for the first time in over 70 years. This occurred despite the country’s temperate climate, and viral phylogenetic analysis suggests that the Japanese outbreak resulted from international travel from Southeast Asia [ 6]. Furthermore, the number of reported dengue cases and outbreaks continues to increase. In 2014, a dengue outbreak affected several Asian countries, including China, Thailand, Vietnam and Japan [ 7, 8].
